data.text:
The Least We Can Do Is Wave to Each Other

Studio album by

Van der Graaf Generator

Released February 1970

Recorded 11–14 December 1969

Studio Trident, London

Genre Progressive rock

Length 43:50

Label Charisma (UK)

Probe (US)

Producer John Anthony

Side one

1. "Darkness (11/11)" 7:28

2. "Refugees" 6:23

3. "White Hammer" 8:15

Side two

4. "Whatever Would Robert Have Said?" 6:07

5. "Out of My Book" Hammill, David Jackson 4:08

6. "After the Flood" 11:27

Bonus tracks on reissue, originally the B- and A-sides of an April 1970 single

7. "Boat of Millions of Years" 3:50

8. "Refugees" 5:24

Peter Hammill – acoustic guitar and lead vocals; piano on "Refugees"

David Jackson – tenor and alto saxophone, flute and backing vocals

Hugh Banton – organ, piano and backing vocals

Nic Potter – bass guitar and electric guitar

Guy Evans – Drums and percussion

Additional musicians

Mike Hurwitz – cello on "Refugees"

Gerry Salisbury – cornet on "White Hammer"

Production

Van der Graaf Generator – arrangements

John Anthony – producer

Robin Geoffrey Cable – recording and engineering

The band's second album was released in February of 1970, and was the band's first album to come out on the Charisma label, after the issues with the debut single and the debut album and the label wrestling and contract issues, the band finally had a home base to work from.

All the tracks were written by Hammill except for Out Of My Book which is co-credited with David Jackson who comes into the band on the wind instruments, and we do notice a change in the sound somewhat.

This album also charted at 47 in the UK, which surely would have given the guys a bit of a lift, knowing that people were actually buying the album.

It is actually the band's only album to crack the top fifty.

It's also worth noting that this was actually the first album to be released in the UK, if anyone missed that in the previous write up.

In many ways this could be considered the band's debut album, when the first was supposed to have been released as a Hammill solo album, and only available in the US.

This time contractual obligations didn't get in the way, and the intention of the album is clear.

Rehearsals for the album began in September 1969.

Hammill brought the songs to the band as completed tracks that he could play along with, but Banton and Jackson were heavily involved in the arrangements, and the whole band improvised quite a bit together.

Banton had a background as a church organist, and he felt his love for modern French classic music fitted well with Hammill's writing.

The album was recorded from the eleventh to the fourteenth of December in 1969 at Trident Studios with John Anthony producing.

The album was recorded on an 8-track reel to reel, except After The Flood which used a 16-track machine.

Guy Evans has said that Producer, Anthony, was a very good organiser, who apparently recognised Hammill's intelligence and artistic capabilities.

The album was released in February 1970, and Smith, although having been hands off, was unhappy with Anthony's mix, so he called in Shel Talmy to remix it.

The first pressings of the album are actually Talmy's remix, but the band were unhappy with Talmy's remix, and persuaded Charisma to allow Anthony to mix the album again, and see if they could please both parties.

The sleeve dedicated the album to "L & M, without whom everyone would have been much happier", a criticism of Lou Reizner and Mercury Records.

The title is taken from artist John Minton: "We're all awash in a sea of blood, and the least we can do is wave to each other."

The album received favourable reviews

A review in International Times said the album was the best debut since King Crimson's In the Court of the Crimson King, while a reviewer in Time Out said it was "the strongest thing I've heard in a long time".

Modern reviews

In the Q & Mojo Classic Special Edition Pink Floyd & The Story of Prog Rock, the album came #15 in its list of "40 Cosmic Rock Albums".

François Couture, reviewing the album in AllMusic, described Hammill's distorted delivery of the word "Annihilation" in "After the Flood" to be "one of the scariest moments in the history of British prog rock".

In his 1997 History of Progressive Rock, Paul Stump assessed that while the album is harmonically and structurally similar to contemporary progressive rock works by Genesis and Yes, it does contain hints of the more unique work Van der Graaf Generator would later produce, particularly Jackson's "snaggling, niggling Coltrane-ish saxophone".

So having had a chance to listen to this album a couple of times now, I like this quite a bit.

It is an album I had never even heard of until we decided to give this thread a go.

I can certainly hear influence/inspiration from what we now consider contemporary prog bands, but even so, the band manage to have their own sound.

Part of that seems to come from Hammill's unique vocal delivery, which is an interesting style that generally has good enunciation, not generally common in rock music, and an almost theatrical over the top element that gives the songs a fairly different sound and feel to many of the band's contemporaries.

Darkness (11/11).

The 11/11 addition to the title of the track came from the song being written November 11 1968.

The opening sound effects were taken from the BBC archive by Anthony, and give us a suitably eerie intro to the album.

We get this slow build come into the picture, and some nice hats clicking away.

The bass sets the feel with a really nice little groove.

The somewhat whispered vocal is very effective in conveying the idea of darkness.

The chorus is excellent and really adds a nice flavour to the song.

Again the descending pattern, until the change, which has an aggressive ominous kind of feel to it.

The keyboard break, builds nicely, with a sort of held chord and then moves into a nice sort of chordal lead.

I really like the groove of this song, and I wasn't expecting to have much in the way of grooves on this thread. So that's encouraging, and also.

The drummer is really very good, and I enjoy his style of playing.

This is an excellent opening to the album, and Jackson's double sax fun.... playing them both at the same time (inspired by Roland Kirk, is really very cool, and gives us another texture to digest.... It makes me wonder if Morphine's Dana Colley drew inspiration from Jackson, or perhaps Kirk himself.... it's a neat party trick, but even better when musically effective, as it is here, and frequently in Morphine also.

Refugees .

After the intensity of the opening track we get a much more pastoral opening here.

Hammill delivers a falsetto vocal that slides into his regular voice, and it adds to the gentle feel being presented.

Just after about the two minute mark we get a sort of change in feel.

That seems to be in anticipation of the freedom promised, and the enthusiasm it brings.

Then we move back into the beautiful rolling style of the opening.

Then we move into the change again, and there is a little more intensity this time.

There is a real tenderness to this track, and going through the catalog like this is helping me to become more comfortable with Hammill's vocals.

We get a choir of backing vocals that lift up the song a bit more, as the hope and enthusiasm of those looking for a new home grows.... and then we move out of the song with a nice little instrumental section that has the feel of arrival in the new land.

White Hammer.

We open with what feels like Banton's church organ roots, and it works as a sort of mini-overture to the song.

Hammill comes in on the vocals and then the song gets a bit more punch, and when one takes into account what the song is about, it makes complete sense.

This is an historically based ballad, in the true sense of the word, and the music chosen to accompany it is quite interesting in its dynamic change ups.

We have mellow and smooth.

We have intense and brash.

We also get a lovely melodic section that could almost be a pop song of some sort.

After a short instrumental section we get a very quiet organ section and then that busts into an aurally violent grind... that verges on heavy metal, just without the predominant guitars.

Then we come to a dramatic dead stop.

Whatever Would Robert Have Said?.

Here we get an ascending organ chord pattern, and the instruments introduce themselves as we move along.... Again, I'm really enjoying the drumming from Guy Evans.

We get a tacet and the vocal comes in unaccompanied, Hammill singing in likely his lowest register.

Gradually the instruments come in, but it stays low key.

Then we end this section with a very cool harmony vocal.

Interestingly the next section starts with a melody guitar, playing a nice distorted melody line while the vocal continues.

I guess it's interesting to me, as I wasn't really expecting much in the way of guitar from what people have said in the earlier part of the thread.... This isn't highly technical or anything, but it is, yet again, a nice textural change.

I like when bands don't lock themselves into rules. Here, even with the option of the wind instruments and keys, we get what I think is the first upfront guitar, particularly in a lead line styling.

Again the dynamics work really well for me. I like music to give us good dynamics, and these guys are really moving from quiet to loud and volatile in thought provoking ways.

Just before the end we get a really cool acoustic guitar section that somewhat reflects the debut album, and we build to a dramatic finish.

Out Of My Book .

Here we have Hammill and Jackson combining on the writing, and we get a really nice melodic and smooth track that brings another texture to the album.

It strikes me, at the stage at least, that the guys work really well together, and the group arrangements give everyone space to shine, and accentuate the song's structure well.

The layers of wind instruments work really well here also.

I suppose to some degree this also reflects the debut a little, reaching back into that late sixties sound and feel.

After The Flood.

So we come to the epic closing track.

We open with a very cool unison melody/harmony line, and then drop into an acoustic guitar and vocal.

The change initially comes in like a Gentle Giant type of change, and we get this manic staccato change that is accented really nicely.

Then we change up again, to a melodic section that breaks down into a drone that builds into a percussive section.

A smooth melodic section rolls into the picture.

Then we move into a section that has a kind of baroque folk feel.

Rather than follow this line, I'm going to say that we get these ever changing sections linked together to give the feel of the disaster being shared.

Melodic sections interspersed with manic instrumental sections that share a feel, rather than a specific melody.

Some frantic sax playing leads us into a nice mellow acoustic section that builds and dramatically leads to the effected "Total Annihilation"

This could be a science fiction piece, or it could be indirectly an impression of the flood of Noah's days. Either way it manages to capture a lot of different feels that reflect a lot of different emotions that would accompany such an event.

All this leads to a cool outro piece of music that again has a nice bit of guitar in there.

Giving way to a crossfaded white sound, and finally a silence, for one to ponder all that has gone before.

This is a really solid album, and steps closer to the sound of the band that I am much more familiar with, on what I believe to be four of the most vaunted albums in the VdGG catalog.

I really enjoyed going through this album, and it has helped me to get closer to Hammill's vocals in the dynamic sense of how they work with the music. Perhaps not a classic singer as such, but in unison with what it appears the band are trying to accomplish, it works really very well.

So they are my newbie thoughts and feelings in regards to this album, which manages to be soothing and disturbing, melodic and chaotic, and does all I ask an album of this type to do, take me on a journey.

So let us know what you think of this album....

The when, where, how stuff.

The feelings it gave/gives you.

Essentially, just share your heart and mind on The Least We Can Do Is Wave To Each Other.

Darkness

Day dawns dark

It now numbers

Infinity

Life crawls from the past

Watching in wonder

I trace its patterns in me

Tomorrow's tomorrow is birth again

Boats burn the bridge in the fens

The time of the past returns to my life

And uses it

Don't blame me

For the letters that may

Form in the sand

Don't look in my eyes

You may see all the numbers

That stretch in my sky

And colour my hand

Don't say that I'm wrong in imagining

That the voice of my life cannot sing

Fate enters and talks in old words

They amuse it

Hands shine darkly and white

Only in dark, they appear

Bless the baby born today (wicked little)

Flying in pitch (Scorpio doomed to die a thousand times)

Flying on fear (before he lives)

They shine in my eyes and touch my face

Where I have seen them placed before

Don't blame me, please, for the fate that falls

I did not choose it

I did not choose it

I did not

No, no, I did not

I truly did not choose it

Songwriters: Peter Hammill

Darkness (11/11) lyrics © Stratsong Limited, Carlin Music Corp

I like the lyric here. It seems to speak to a number of things actually, though shrouded in a sort of mystery sheen of poetic license.

The opening verse seems to speak to the idea of the history of life playing out through its modern inhabitants.

Then we get the idea of the past constantly being repeated and the writer observes this in his own life, and the way life continually shows us pictures of ourselves matched against history, and how we are used in ways that we often don't understand, to achieve goals that we equally don't understand.... in a macro sense.

Then we get the idea of not blaming this person for being involved in this perpetuation of the process of life itself. and all the curve balls it throws.

"Don't blame me for the letters that may form in the sand" is a great line and it speaks to the fact that we only have control over two things in our lives, our actions and reactions.

I learned long ago that everything else was completely out of my control, and it can sometimes be a hard lesson in the way we learn this.

The second change lyric kind of makes me laugh a little, because it seems almost like a shrouded dig at his own singing, and the fate that led him to be the singer of the band, but it could also have the double meaning of, if life is seen as the song we sing, mixed with fates we face, then our journey will walk in paths well trodden

"Fate enters and talks in old words" ... i love this line, and like most of the lyric, could be broadly interpreted into many meanings, but in keeping with the general flow of this poem, it again speaks to the idea that all that is happening as happened before in one way or another. With the old words being things gone before.

They amuse it, is an interesting full stop at the end of this sentence.

The old words amuse fate, as tied to the grand picture, fate has seen this game before, and heard the old words virtually an infinite amount of times.

The next section makes this personal, in the reflected lyric.

"wicked little Scorpio doomed to die a thousand times before he lives"

Hammill was born November 5th 1948, and so is indeed a Scorpio for those into that kind of thing.... and being a Halloween 68 baby, I'm a Scorpio almost exactly twenty years younger.

This is where we seem to get to the heart of the darkness in the lyric.

His hands shine darkly... only in dark, they appear... which could be his hands, or perhaps the old voices from the previous section.

But it goes on to say "Bless the baby born today"....

In the US rebirthing (an apparently somewhat dangerous practice, that is supposed to help heal childhood trauma) started to gain traction in 1974 ... which is a few years away, but perhaps Hammill read up about it, or experienced it?

Though again with the way the whole lyric is set up, it could be some kind of reference to his birth into the band, as a musician etc etc...

Flying in pitch, would appear to be akin to travelling blind. Flying in utter darkness. Essentially moving forward without any idea of where you're going, but needing to move forward anyway.

Flying On fear.... gives the idea of, again, moving forward in light of the feeling of being surrounded by darkness, an inability to see a path, and the consequence is flying forward in fear of the unseen lurking around every corner of life.

That last section is again somewhat cryptic, and appears to be talking about the hands.... but are they his hands?

I notice from my looking around at who I am dealing with here, because I am completely foreign to Hammill, and only really vaguely familiar and new to the band, that he has some songs about mental health facilities.... perhaps this is about the darkness of mental health issues, and the associated treatments back in the day.

Perhaps the old words and such, are referring to old knowledge about how to deal with these things. The shining hands could be related as a kind of poetic painting of electro-shock therapy......

Anyway.... Sorry if my attempt to get under the skin of the lyrics is way off, or stupid, or irritating.... and somebody will probably come along now and say, in his book Hammill said this lol....

But I really enjoy trying to dig into lyrics, even rather cryptic, poetic ones
